articles.title: The European Union supports strengthening cooperation between Bulgaria and the Republic of North Macedonia, said Valentina Superti from the EC
articles.summary: In the Bulgarian village of Gyueshevo, an Agreement on Transport Connectivity between Bulgaria and the Republic of North Macedonia was signed.
articles.content:
In the Bulgarian village of Gyueshevo, an Agreement on Transport Connectivity between Bulgaria and the Republic of North Macedonia was signed.

GYUESHEVO – The European Union (EU) supports strengthening cooperation between Bulgaria and the Republic of North Macedonia (RNM). This was stated in the village of Gyueshevo, Bulgaria, by Valentina Superti, Director for the Western Balkans at the Directorate-General for Neighborhood and Enlargement Negotiations of the European Commission (EC), after the Bulgarian Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Transport and Communications Grozdán Karadzhov and the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Transport of RNM Alexander Nikoloski signed a Transport Connectivity Agreement between the two countries.

The agreement for the preparation, construction, and operation of the cross-border railway tunnel between Bulgaria and RNM is important for both countries, as well as for the region, for the EU as a whole and for its member states, Superti pointed out. Together with its partners, the EU provides significant financial assistance for this important project. We rely on your leadership to ensure that the agreement will be effectively and timely implemented, she added.

Superti noted that the construction of the tunnel along Corridor 8 is part of the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) – a leading initiative within the “Global Gateway” strategy, which will bring broad social and economic benefits to the region. This will improve transport services, expand access to the EU and the global market, and sustainable transport will strengthen the region’s competitiveness.

By signing this agreement, we are bringing to life a 138-year-old idea from the drawing of the first Balkan railway and the initiation of the connection between Sofia and Skopje, said the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Transport of Bulgaria, Bulgarian Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Transport and Communications Grozdán Karadzhov. He thanked the international partners and financial institutions, the ambassadors of the EU and NATO countries for the renewal of the project.

The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Transport of the Republic of North Macedonia, Alexander Nikoloski, emphasized that this is one of the most important transport corridors with strategic, economic, and geopolitical significance for the Balkans and all of Europe.

The cross-border tunnel is a key element of the transport corridor “Western Balkans – Eastern Mediterranean” and the strategic Corridor 8, the Bulgarian Ministry of Transport informed. Its realization will provide the missing railway connectivity between Bulgaria and the Republic of North Macedonia and will improve transport access between the Black Sea and the Adriatic.

Corridor 8 connects the Adriatic Sea with the Black Sea through Albania, the Republic of North Macedonia, and Bulgaria, the ministry added. Minister Karadzhov explained that the railway part of Corridor 8 is approximately 1350 km long, of which 747 km are on Bulgarian territory, and in Bulgaria, only the last 2.4-kilometer border section between Gyueshevo and Deve Bair remains to be built. (06.11.2025)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant international agreement supported by the EU to build a cross-border railway tunnel between Bulgaria and North Macedonia, which will improve regional connectivity, economic integration, and sustainable transport. This infrastructure project has broad social and economic benefits for the Balkans and the wider European region, supported by substantial EU funding and aligned with major EU initiatives like the Trans-European Transport Network and the Global Gateway strategy. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a tangible positive development with wide-reaching impact.
articles.personality_title: Bulgaria and North Macedonia sign agreement for new cross-border railway tunnel
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Bulgaria and the Republic of North Macedonia have long sought better transport links to boost trade and travel between their countries. The European Union supports projects that improve connections in the Western Balkans region.

**What happened** – On November 6, 2025, in the Bulgarian village of Gyueshevo, officials from both countries signed an agreement to build a railway tunnel at their border. This tunnel will complete an important rail section along Corridor 8, which connects the Adriatic Sea to the Black Sea through Albania, North Macedonia, and Bulgaria.

**Impact** – The tunnel project will improve transport between the two countries and beyond, making travel faster and easier. It will also connect markets and help businesses reach more customers. The project is part of the EU’s Trans-European Transport Network and Global Gateway strategy, which aims to support sustainable and modern infrastructure. The EU is providing significant financial help to make this happen.

**What’s next step** – After the agreement, work will begin on building the last 2.4 kilometers of railway between the Bulgarian village of Gyueshevo and the border point Deve Bair. Leaders from both countries will oversee the project to ensure it finishes on time and meets the needs of the region.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Bulgaria and North Macedonia are building a new railway tunnel with EU support to improve transport, trade, and cooperation in the Western Balkans region.

articles.personality_title_es: Bulgaria y Macedonia del Norte firman acuerdo para nuevo túnel ferroviario transfronterizo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Bulgaria y la República de Macedonia del Norte han buscado durante mucho tiempo mejorar sus conexiones de transporte para fomentar el comercio y los viajes entre ambos países. La Unión Europea apoya proyectos que fortalecen las conexiones en la región de los Balcanes Occidentales.

**Qué pasó** – El 6 de noviembre de 2025, en la aldea búlgara de Gyueshevo, funcionarios de ambos países firmaron un acuerdo para construir un túnel ferroviario en la frontera. Este túnel completará una sección importante a lo largo del Corredor 8, que conecta el mar Adriático con el mar Negro pasando por Albania, Macedonia del Norte y Bulgaria.

**Impacto** – El proyecto del túnel mejorará el transporte entre los dos países y más allá, haciendo que los viajes sean más rápidos y fáciles. También conectará mercados y ayudará a las empresas a llegar a más clientes. El proyecto forma parte de la Red Transeuropea de Transporte de la UE y la estrategia Global Gateway, que apoya infraestructuras sostenibles y modernas. La UE está proporcionando una ayuda financiera significativa para hacerlo posible.

**Próximo paso** – Tras el acuerdo, comenzarán las obras para construir los últimos 2,4 kilómetros de ferrocarril entre la aldea búlgara de Gyueshevo y el punto fronterizo Deve Bair. Los líderes de ambos países supervisarán el proyecto para asegurar que se complete a tiempo y satisfaga las necesidades de la región.

**Una frase clave** – Bulgaria y Macedonia del Norte están construyendo un nuevo túnel ferroviario con el apoyo de la UE para mejorar el transporte, el comercio y la cooperación en la región de los Balcanes Occidentales.

articles.title: 'We had to create a human chain to evacuate' - Jamaican hospital rebuilds after hurricane
articles.summary: The heaps of twisted building material and water damaged equipment is being cleared as Jamaicans recover from Hurricane Melissa.
articles.content:
'We had to create a human chain to evacuate' - Jamaican hospital rebuilds after hurricane

9 hours ago Share Save Nick Davis in Falmouth, Jamaica Share Save

Watch: BBC visits battered hospital in Jamaica as recovery underway

As you drive into Falmouth, there's still a moat of dirty looking standing water surrounding the town. On the coastal road, as you slowly push forward in the car, the bow wave breaks and you are hit by the smell of sewage. Passing cars drive slowly so as to not send the spray through the window. This part of the historic town was hit badly by Hurricane Melissa. The regional hospital is on the low-lying road that is the western route into its centre. It was flooded as the water swept across the mangrove and into the facility. Donna-Marie Hamilton-Wallace, the head of nursing at the hospital, was on duty at the time. "It was devastating for the patients and the staff, the lower level was flooded because of the storm surge and we had to create a human chain to evacuate them to the higher level," she said. "It was frightening but I'm glad patients and staff are all okay." I first visited the hospital the morning after the storm hit. Orderlies were clearing rubble from buildings, without sleep for days facing an insurmountable challenge.

Royal Navy

The high winds had ripped off the roof of wards and left infrastructure, like its boiler room, under four feet (1.2m) of water. Now, 10 days later, I'm back and things are slowly improving. At least 32 people have died since the storm ravaged Jamaica, causing some $7bn (£5.3bn) in damage, Jamaican Prime Minister Andrew Holness said. Haiti and other parts of the Caribbean were also destroyed when the Category 5 storm pummelled through the region. 'No help, no food, no water': Hurricane-hit Jamaican towns desperately wait for aid

'We need food, we have no food' - desperation takes hold in Jamaica after hurricane The heaps of twisted building material and water-damaged equipment is being cleared by men and women from the Royal Navy and Commandos from the Army's Crisis Response Troop. There are helping hands, too, from a Spanish team who are here to build a field hospital. Essential for getting scrubs clean and bedding washed, the laundry is still in a terrible state, its roof now just exposed beams. That is the next job for a group of the Commandos, working out how to fix problems with few options that desperately need a solution. The team inside the boiler room includes local workers and Naomi Pearmine, a Marine Engineer. Her job as a technician is normally to look after the fuel system, the engines and propulsion of HMS Trent, the Royal Navy offshore patrol vessel that is tasked with helping here in Jamaica.

Royal Navy

She normally would not take part in missions like this, but getting the ignition going is key to getting the hospital operational. Machelle Stubbs, the chief medical officer at the hospital, explained how important it is to get help at this point. "Many of our staff are still here, working," she said. "Not getting a chance to look after their own personal challenges, that compounds the problems even more. Fortunately we're getting relief from other parts of the island and other international agencies." 'No inch here was spared': Hurricane Melissa destroys Jamaica town Clean-up teams from Jamaica's health ministry came in last weekend, carried in on Jamaica's bright yellow public buses to help their colleagues in need.

ORLANDO BARRIA/EPA/Shutterstock

But today it is help from abroad that is essential. HMS Trent was sent to the Caribbean to provide assistance to British Overseas Territories and Commonwealth Nations during hurricane season. First Lt Jacob Mikurenda is the second in command. He said that for sailors on this deployment it is a chance to put all their skills together in a situation that's different from their normal duty. For many sailors, this deployment - to provide humanitarian aid and disaster relief - was the first land operation of their careers. "It's been amazing to see the resilience and the community of the people to recover after the hurricane," Mr Mikurenda said. The scale of the disaster can be seen in the little details as well as the big ones. The staff hung sheets on make-shift washing lines running along the walkways to the wards. There are crumpled signs for hospital departments strewn on the ground and medical records drying on a tarpaulin between the admin offices. Keriesa Bell Cummings the hospital's CEO summed it up: "It's traumatising it really is but as the leader here I have to stay strong."

Royal Navy

She has been organising people from around the world - diplomats, helpers from hospitals in other less affected parts of the island and the country's health ministry - to help with the efforts. Initially she said she was too busy to be interviewed, but then she wanted to express that things were coming back to normal. "A lot of material support, relief, tools, labour, food, we asked for it and it's now coming," Ms Cummings said. Communications are still an issue here in Falmouth and our region, but there is hope it gets better in the days to come. WhatsApp and phone are still patchy, making calls difficult and co-ordination almost impossible. But this week is better than last, a feeling most Jamaicans are clinging on to.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the ongoing recovery and rebuilding efforts at a Jamaican hospital after devastating damage caused by Hurricane Melissa. It highlights the resilience and cooperation of local staff, international military aid, and humanitarian teams working together to restore essential health services. The story has broad significance as it reflects disaster recovery and humanitarian aid impacting a community and potentially others affected by similar disasters. It provides sufficient detail about the challenges faced and the positive progress being made, making it an inspiring story of recovery and hope.
articles.personality_title: Jamaican hospital rebuilds with help after Hurricane Melissa
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Hurricane Melissa hit Jamaica hard, flooding the town of Falmouth and severely damaging its regional hospital. The storm caused widespread destruction, including flooding and roof damage, making it unsafe and difficult for patients and staff.

**What happened** – During the hurricane, hospital staff had to form a human chain to move patients to higher floors and keep them safe. In the days after, local workers, the Royal Navy, Army Commandos, and an international Spanish team joined forces to clear rubble, fix damaged equipment, and begin rebuilding. The hospital’s boiler room and laundry were flooded, and efforts are underway to repair these vital areas.

**Impact** – The hospital supports many patients and staff who faced tough conditions but stayed to help. The teamwork between local people and international helpers has been crucial to restoring health services. This cooperation shows how communities and aid groups can work together to overcome disaster challenges and save lives.

**What's next step** – Repair work will continue on the hospital’s damaged areas, especially the laundry and boiler room, to make sure it can operate fully again. Communication systems will also be improved to help coordinate ongoing relief efforts. The hospital hopes to return to normal service soon with support from across Jamaica and abroad.

**One-sentence takeaway** – After Hurricane Melissa, a Jamaican hospital is slowly rebuilding thanks to the combined efforts of local staff and international aid teams working together to restore care.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un hôpital jamaïcain reconstruit avec de l'aide après l’ouragan Melissa
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’ouragan Melissa a frappé durement la Jamaïque, inondant la ville de Falmouth et endommageant gravement son hôpital régional. La tempête a causé des dégâts importants, rendant l’hôpital dangereux pour les patients et le personnel.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Pendant l’ouragan, le personnel a formé une chaîne humaine pour déplacer les patients vers les étages supérieurs et assurer leur sécurité. Dans les jours qui ont suivi, des travailleurs locaux, la Royal Navy, des commandos de l’armée et une équipe espagnole ont uni leurs forces pour dégager les débris, réparer le matériel endommagé et commencer la reconstruction. La chaufferie et la buanderie de l’hôpital ont été inondées et les réparations sont en cours.

**Impact** – L’hôpital soutient de nombreux patients et employés qui ont tenu bon malgré les difficultés. La coopération entre la population locale et les aides internationales a été essentielle pour restaurer les services de santé. Cette collaboration montre comment les communautés et les groupes d’aide peuvent s’unir pour surmonter les catastrophes et sauver des vies.

**Prochaine étape** – Les travaux de réparation vont continuer, surtout pour la buanderie et la chaufferie, afin que l’hôpital puisse fonctionner pleinement à nouveau. Les systèmes de communication seront aussi améliorés pour mieux coordonner les secours. L’hôpital espère revenir à un service normal bientôt avec le soutien de la Jamaïque et de l’étranger.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Après l’ouragan Melissa, un hôpital jamaïcain se reconstruit lentement grâce à la coopération du personnel local et des équipes d’aide internationales.
articles.personality_title_es: Hospital jamaicano se reconstruye con ayuda tras el huracán Melissa
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El huracán Melissa golpeó fuerte a Jamaica, inundando la ciudad de Falmouth y dañando gravemente su hospital regional. La tormenta causó destrucción que hizo inseguro el hospital para pacientes y personal.

**Qué pasó** – Durante el huracán, el personal formó una cadena humana para mover a los pacientes a pisos más altos y mantenerlos seguros. En los días siguientes, trabajadores locales, la Marina Real, comandos del ejército y un equipo español trabajaron juntos para limpiar escombros, reparar equipos dañados y comenzar la reconstrucción. La sala de calderas y la lavandería del hospital estaban inundadas y están siendo reparadas.

**Impacto** – El hospital apoya a muchos pacientes y trabajadores que permanecieron a pesar de las dificultades. La cooperación entre la comunidad local y los equipos internacionales ha sido clave para restaurar los servicios de salud. Esta colaboración muestra cómo las comunidades y los grupos de ayuda pueden unirse para superar desastres y salvar vidas.

**Próximo paso** – Continuarán las reparaciones en las áreas dañadas, especialmente en la lavandería y la sala de calderas, para que el hospital funcione completamente. También mejorarán las comunicaciones para coordinar mejor la ayuda. Se espera que el hospital vuelva pronto a la normalidad con apoyo nacional e internacional.

**Resumen en una frase** – Tras el huracán Melissa, un hospital jamaicano se reconstruye poco a poco gracias al trabajo conjunto de su personal local y equipos internacionales de ayuda.
